description.narrative:
Olof Palme International Center (OPC) har inkommit med en ansökan till Sida om finansiering av 6,2 miljoner SEK för att genomföra "Medborgarnas deltagande för ansvarsfullt och öppet styre mot social rättvisa i Nord Makedonien" under perioden januari 2020 - december 2021.
Insatsen syftar till att stärka det civila samhällets organisationers kapacitet och legitimitet och stödja aktiviteter som säkerställer deltagande i politiska, sociala och ekonomiska processer och ansvarsutkrävande av ansvarstagare. Organisationer i det civila samhället kommer att mobilisera medborgarna och öka deltagandet i beslutsprocesser, förbättra öppenheten och ansvarsutkrävande, samt säkerställa respekten för socioekonomiska rättigheter.
Förväntade resultat av insatsen: 1. Programmet avser att se partnerorganisationer stärka deras legitimitet, bygga allianser för gemensamma åtgärder för att påverka politiska dagordningar och ha kapacitet att övervaka genomförandet av politiska beslut. 2. Programmet har för avsikt att se stärkta medborgare och civilsamhällets organisationer som är organiserade, aktivt deltar i och påverkar beslutsprocesser, kräver öppenhet och ansvarutkrävande av ansvarstagare. 3. Programmet har för avsikt att se arsvarstagare följa bestämmelser som rör transparens och ansvarsutkrävande, samarbeta med relevanta delar av det civila samhället och inkludera dem i beslutsprocesser.
OPCs samarbete bygger på stöd till enskilda projekt såväl som till nätverk och allianser som samlas kring gemensamma frågor/komponenter i programmet.

Olof Palme International Center (OPC) has applied to Sida for funding of 6,2 million SEK to carry out the "Citizens´ participation for accountable and transparent governance towards social justice in North Macedonia" during the period January 2020 - December 2021.
The intervention aims to strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and support activities that ensure the participatory nature of political, social and economic processes and the accountability of duty bearers. Civil society organisations will mobilize citizens and increase participation in decision-making processes, improve transparency and accountability and ensure respect for socio-economic rights.
Expected outcomes of the intervention: 1. The programme intends to see partner organisations strengthen their legitimacy, build alliances for joint actions to influence policy agendas and have capacities to monitor the implementation of political decisions. 2. The programme intends to see empowered citizens and civil society organisations be organised and actively participate and influence decision-making processes, demanding transparency and accountability of duty bearers. 3. The programme intends to see duty-bearers abide to regulations related to transparency and accountability, cooperate with relevant parts of civil society and include them in decision-making processes.
OPC´s cooperation builds on support to individual Projects as well as to networks and Alliances gathered around common issues/components of the program.
The direct target group is programme partner organisations. The indirect target groups, reached by the programme partners, are citizens/organized citizen groups and duty bearers.

The overall objective of the intervention and the project objective, as described in the programme document (and copied in the below) and assessed in the initial appraisal, have not changed. OPC base their work in the region on their International strategy which is valid 2020-2025.
However when it comes to the expected objectives/outcome challenges, OPC mentions that they consider most of their partners now are mature and internally consolidated organisations, and the focus of the work in 2022 is therefore on outcome challenges 2 and 3:
2. The programme intends to see empowered citizens and civil society organisations be organised and actively participate and influence decision-making processes, demanding transparency and accountability of duty bearers.
3. The programme intends to see duty-bearers abide to regulations related to transparency and accountability, cooperate with relevant parts of civil society and include them in decision-making processes.
The overall objective of the intervention (vision) is to contribute to: Political and social processes in North Macedonia that are transparent and participatory,reflecting the rights and interests of empowered and organized citizens that hold duty-bearers accountable.
The project objective (mission) is: To strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and support activities that ensure the participatory nature of political, social and economic processes and the accountability of duty bearers. Civil society organisation will mobilize citizens and increase popular participation in decision-making processes, improve transparency and accountability and ensure respect for socio-economic rights.

description.narrative:
Below is a summary of results that the partner have reached, focusing on the period 1 January - 31 December 2021.
In 2021, OPC continued to support the strengthening of the democratic processes and the civil society organizations in North Macedonia by working with eight collaborations (partners/networks): NGO Info-centre, SIER (Trade Union of Industry, Energy and Mining of Macedonia), Glasen Tekstilec, MCB/YCC Bitola (Youth Cultural Center), Multicultura Tetovo, Foundation for debate and education IDEA Southeast Europe, HTO (Housing and tenant's organisation) and a coalition of all OPC partners and other CSOs.
The continued Covid-19 pandemic created a number of challenges but partners were able to swiftly adapt to the online working techniques, based on lessons learned from the first year of pandemic, and focus on monitoring good governance procedures. OPC continued using outcome mapping as the managing methodology to focus the programme strategically on targeted actors and thematic areas. This methodology provides stronger ownership and direct involvement of all actors in identifying challenges and set realistic expectations based on clearly defined objectives and progress markers.
At the start of the year OPC held weekly online meetings with their partner organisations and then did monthly meetings. Apart from these on-line events, physical visits were also done when possible in accordance with the restrictions in place. The local programme manager is financed through the Kosovo programme and when setting up the programme in North Macedonia, OPC asked Sida if they could share these costs between the programmes but Sida then stated that national programmes can only finance staff in one country and that Sida Pristina and Skopje were ok with this arrangement.
Although the pandemic brought uncertainties for OPC's partner organisations and their work, the annual report for 2021 shows that to a large extent they were able to adapt to online working methods and focused on monitoring good governance practices. Despite restrictions due to the pandemic, OPC's partners provided spaces for interaction and demanded accountability of the duty bearers in addressing citizens issues (not the least in connection with the local elections), for instance around lack of access to information and lack of transparency of institutions. The major deviation relates to the budget line "internal contribution" which was planned for regional capacity building, networking and conferences, as well as several exchanges between Macedonian and Swedish organisations. OPC states that the planned exchanges will hopefully take place in 2022 but as the pandemic created a backlog among all organizations it is difficult to implement all activities that have been postponed for 2 years.
The narrative report of 2020 primarily focused on the progress linked to OPC's direct boundary partners (their partner organisations). In this regards, steps have been taken towards the outcome challenge: The programme intends to see partner organisations strengthen their legitimacy, build alliances for joint actions to influence policy agendas and have capacities to monitor the implementation of political decisions. and its four target areas: 1) sustainability and legitimacy, 2) use of participatory mechanisms, 3) coalition and networking, 4) monitoring and advocacy.
Within the first target area, Glasen Tekstilec continued strengthening internal procedures by updating all administrative and financial documents provided by an external accounting company and the association's legal counsel. A new budget allocation mechanism has been established which is publicly disclosed and improve internal capacities and assure transparency and sustainability.
In the second target area, SIER organized trainings with their Health&Safety representatives and the responsible authorities in order to assist the members to manage the situation at the workplaces caused by the pandemic.
Also, through the consistent work of NGO Info-Centre in several municipalities, mayors and local councils are more open for cooperation with civil society in general. Consequently, the Government and the competent Ministry of Local Self-Government have involved NGO Info-Centre in the work of advancement of mechanisms for the direct participation of citizens in municipal decision-making processes. OPC further states that the Ministry will take into consideration the proposals from NGO Info-centre when drafting amendments to the Law on Local Self-Government.
Within the third target area, the alliance Forum for Civic Dialogue was formed in relation to local elections by five OPC partner organizations (NGO Info Centar, YCC Bitola, Struga Municipality Community Centre; Glasen Tekstilec Stip, Multikultura Tetovo and IDEA Skopje) and three local CSOs (Spektar from Kariva Palanka, Civic Initiative of Women of Sveti Nikole, and the Media Development Centre from Skopje). The network supported active involvement of local governments, institutions in including citizens in developing local policies and decision-making processes. They organized 18 consultative meetings in 9 municipalities, 9 public debates with Mayor and Municipal Council candidates, and 9 meetings with elected Mayors and representatives in Municipal Councils.
Finally, in the forth target area, YCC Bitola contributed to the monitoring of the LESCs through participation in forums and debates organized in the frame of the project regarding the work of these councils. They are also a part and play an active role in the working group for preparing amendments on the Law on volunteerism and development of the new Strategy for promotion of volunteering in Republic of North Macedonia, adopted in September 2021.
Altogether, the report shows that while the pandemic challenged OPC and its partner organisations, they also managed to quickly adapt to new circumstances in order to ensure a continuation in the implementation of the programme. It also shows that they were able to handle the situation and, by working in new ways, still making progress towards the overall aim of the programme.
